description: From Middle English infiltrate (adj), from Medieval Latin infiltrātus, from infiltrō.

entries.meaning: (pathology) Any undesirable substance or group of cells that has made its way into part of the body.
examples: One critical distinction to make is whether a focal corneal infiltrate is infected with bacteria or is a sterile immunologic response.

verbs.description: infiltrate (third-person singular simple present infiltrates, present participle infiltrating, simple past and past participle infiltrated)

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To surreptitiously penetrate, enter or gain access to.
examples: The spy infiltrated the high-tech company and stole many secrets.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cause to penetrate in this way.
examples: The agency infiltrated several spies into the company.

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive, of a liquid) To pass through something by filtration.
(transitive) To cause (a liquid) to pass through something by filtration.
(transitive, intransitive, medicine) To invade or penetrate a tissue or organ.
examples: High-grade tumors often infiltrate surrounding structures.
In certain conditions, immune cells may infiltrate into the cerebrospinal fluid.

entries.meaning: (transitive, military) To send (soldiers, spies, etc.) through gaps in the enemy line.
(intransitive, of an intravenous needle) To move from a vein, remaining in the body.
